raw_text:
Electronics firms eye plasma deal
 
 Consumer electronics giants Hitachi and Matshushita Electric are joining forces to share and develop technology for flat screen televisions.
 
 The tie-up comes as the world's top producers are having to contend with falling prices and intense competition. The two Japanese companies will collaborate in research & development, production, marketing and licensing. They said the agreement would enable the two companies to expand the plasma display TV market globally.
 
 Plasma display panels are used for large, thin TVs which are replacing old-style televisions. The display market for high-definition televisions is split between models using plasma display panels and others - manufactured by the likes of Sony and Samsung - using liquid-crystal displays (LCDs). The deal will enable Hitachi and Matsushita, which makes Panasonic brand products, to develop new technology and improve their competitiveness. Hitachi recently announced a deal to buy plasma display technology from rival Fujitsu in an effort to strengthen its presence in the market.
 
 Separately, Fujitsu announced on Monday that it is quitting the LCD panel market by transferring its operations in the area to Japanese manufacturer Sharp. Sharp will inherit staff, manufacturing facilities and intellectual property from Fujitsu. The plasma panel market has seen rapid consolidation in recent months as the price of consumer electronic goods and components has fallen. Samsung Electronics and Sony are among other companies working together to reduce costs and speed up new product development.
llama3.2:1b: Hitachi and Matshushita Electric are joining forces to share technology for flat screen televisions, with plans to collaborate on research & development, production, marketing, and licensing. The deal aims to expand the plasma display TV market globally and strengthen Hitachi's position in the industry after announcing a deal to buy plasma display technology from Fujitsu.
llama3.2:3b: Electronics firms Hitachi and Matsushita Electric will collaborate on research, production, marketing, and licensing for plasma display TVs. They aim to expand the global market share of plasma panels, which compete with LCDs. The deal comes amid consolidation in the industry, with Fujitsu quitting the LCD panel market and Sharp inheriting its operations.
gemma2:2b: Hitachi and Matsushita Electric are collaborating to share technology for flat-screen televisions, expanding their market share globally. This collaboration will focus on research and development, production, marketing, and licensing of plasma display TV technology.  The move aims to improve competitiveness in the growing high-definition television (HDTV) market, which uses both plasma and LCD panels. In response to falling prices and intense competition, other companies like Fujitsu and Sharp are also consolidating and focusing on specific technologies within the electronics industry.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Hitachi and Matsushita Electric join forces to share technology for flat-screen TVs, enabling them to expand the plasma display TV market globally. Hitachi and Matsushita's agreement will enable them to develop new plasma display panel technology and improve their competitiveness in the industry. The agreement also transfers Fujitsu's LCD panel business operations to Sharp, which is a Japanese manufacturer specializing in plasma panel manufacturing.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Two Japanese electronics firms, Hitachi and Matsushita (Panasonic), have formed a partnership to jointly develop technology for plasma display televisions, aiming to expand the market globally despite falling prices and intense competition in the flat-screen TV industry. This collaboration will include research & development, production, marketing, and licensing. The deal is intended to improve competitiveness by leveraging Hitachi's plasma display technology.
qwen2.5:3b: Consumer electronics giants Hitachi and Matsushita Electric are forming a partnership to share and develop technology for flat screen televisions, facing challenges from falling prices and competition. They will collaborate in research & development, production, marketing, and licensing. Plasma display panels are replacing old TVs; the deal enables both companies to expand their market globally. Meanwhile, Fujitsu is exiting the LCD panel market by transferring operations to Sharp, signaling continued consolidation in the plasma display sector amidst reduced consumer electronic prices.
opencoder:1.5b:
The electronics firms are planning to co-produce technologies for flat-screen televisions. They have collaborated to share and develop the technology, which will help in expanding the global display TV market. Hitachi and Matsushita electric companies are set to jointly research, develop, produce, sell and market their new technology - plasma display panels. The agreement will facilitate the expansion of the market for high-definition televisions globally.
Fujitsu's announcement also indicates that it plans to separate from its LCD panel business in favor of Sharp, setting the precedent for future collaborations. It shares with companies like Panasonic and Samsung, which are already operating in the plasma display technology market, their operations will be transferred, thus strengthening their presence in the market.
Future collaborations may further allow Samsung Electronics and Sony to reduce costs while speeding up new product development. The transition between the two companies, though, does not seem to have a significant impact on consumer electronics' overall performance but is merely an aspect of the joint operation.

tinyllama:1.1b: Hitachi and Matshushita Electric have formed a strategic partnership to collaborate in research, development, production, marketing, and licensing for flat screen television sets using plasma display panels. The agreement will enable the two companies to expand the plasma display TV market globally by improving their competitiveness through technological advancements. The deal was announced on Monday, with Hitachi acquiring Plasmaside technology from rival Fuji Tsushita in an effort to strengthen its presence in the market. This is a significant move as the plasma display panel market has seen rapid consolidation and is now dominated by Sony and Samsuung Electronics. As consumer electronics giants look for new ways to cut costs, this joint venture comes at a time when flat screen television sales are declining due to intense competition.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Consumer electronics giants Hitachi and Matshushita Electric have finalized a deal that will see them share and develop technology for flat screen television displays. The agreement comes amidst falling prices and intense competition in the plasma display TV market, where both companies aim to expand their presence globally. This new partnership will enable them to innovate and improve their competitiveness against major rivals like Sony and Samsung, as well as other smaller manufacturers. The deal is expected to lead to improved technology and a more streamlined supply chain for the market.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Consumer electronics giants Hitachi and Matsushita Electric (Panasonic) have formed a partnership to collaborate on plasma display technology for televisions, aiming to expand the market globally amidst falling prices and intense competition. This alliance will focus on research, development, production, marketing, and licensing. The deal will help both companies enhance their competitiveness in the high-definition TV market, which is dominated by plasma displays (used by Hitachi) and LCDs (manufactured by Sony and Samsung).

Meanwhile, Fujitsu has announced its exit from the liquid crystal display (LCD) panel market by transferring these operations to Sharp. The rapid consolidation in the plasma panel market reflects the impact of declining consumer electronics prices and component costs. Other major players, including Samsung Electronics and Sony, are also partnering to cut costs and accelerate new product development.
reference: Hitachi recently announced a deal to buy plasma display technology from rival Fujitsu in an effort to strengthen its presence in the market.They said the agreement would enable the two companies to expand the plasma display TV market globally.The display market for high-definition televisions is split between models using plasma display panels and others - manufactured by the likes of Sony and Samsung - using liquid-crystal displays (LCDs).Plasma display panels are used for large, thin TVs which are replacing old-style televisions.Separately, Fujitsu announced on Monday that it is quitting the LCD panel market by transferring its operations in the area to Japanese manufacturer Sharp.
